article:
When I started riding a bike a couple of years ago, I didn't think my involvement  would ever be more serious than sometimes short rides. But as I built up  _  , my friends encouraged me to try some  _  trips. The
first one to come along was a 150-mile ride, an annual  _  that
raises money to fight cancer.
When I registered, the idea seemed excellent - to support a  _  cause while riding for a long
distance. But  _  the time for the ride approached, my
self-doubt gained ground   _  my determination.
As a matter of fact, though I  _  want to raise money for the
charity, I didn't really want to bike all those miles for two days  _  .
The ride began on a Sunday morning, and for the first few hours I felt wonderful. This was just the experience I had imagined, and my spirits were high. But by the end of the day, I felt tired and  _  .
If the body is connected to the mind, here is proof in action.
Every  _  my brain pushed
out seemed to travel right down to my legs. "I can't  _  this",
"I've got a cramp ", and "everyone else is a better rider"  _  into shortness of breath. I was sure I'd have to quit.
Then I  _  that the lone
rider in front of me looked different  in some ways  . But she was too
far away for me to  _  why. And so I pushed myself to  catch up  . There she was, riding along slowly but  _  ,
with a slight and determined smile on her face and she had only one leg.
My  _  changed in that
instant. For a whole day I'd been  _  my body. But now I knew
it was the  _  that would help me reach my goal.
It rained all the second day. But I pushed on without complaining. And at the end of the day, still feeling strong, I completed the 150-mile trip.
